tags: I'm not even defending bran as a stark
the show bran is clearly not bran anymore
just tired of her fans not holding her accountable for her actions
but take her as she is
summary: Kinda funny how fandom keeps blaming other characters’s actions on Bran, because apparently knowing the future means you have...
body: Kinda funny how fandom keeps blaming other characters’s actions on Bran, because apparently knowing the future means you have the obligation to stop all wrong doing. Even if Bran could see the future in its entirety, which he can’t, it still wouldn’t have been Bran who torched King’s Landing.

reblog.comment: Kinda funny how fandom keeps blaming other characters’s actions on Bran, because apparently knowing the future means you have the obligation to stop all wrong doing. Even if Bran could see the future in its entirety, which he can’t, it still wouldn’t have been Bran who torched King’s Landing.

trail.content_raw: Kinda funny how fandom keeps blaming other characters’s actions on Bran, because apparently knowing the future means you have the obligation to stop all wrong doing. Even if Bran could see the future in its entirety, which he can’t, it still wouldn’t have been Bran who torched King’s Landing.
trail.content: Kinda funny how fandom keeps blaming other characters’s actions on Bran, because apparently knowing the future means you have the obligation to stop all wrong doing. Even if Bran could see the future in its entirety, which he can’t, it still wouldn’t have been Bran who torched King’s Landing.

blog.title: The North Remembers
blog.description:
Profile photo by @shurakaramzin

GOT fan, History buff, movie lover, elementary school teacher

tags: what was the point of r+l=j ?
westerosis wil soon be scheming to put him on the throne
body:
Bittersweet.

I have tried to understand why I found the finale so unsatisfying beyond the obvious, no need to repeat what’s being said already about sacrificing Jon in Dorito’s altar. It mainly revolves around two characters. (Sorry Briemie fans I know Jamie wasn’t written right but I always thought he would come back to Cersei and die with her).

1. Bran.

And for extension Tyrion. Bran has zero political experience and I hardly doubt the 3ER will care for “tax policies”. Also, does knowing all mean he cannot be poisoned because he would see it coming? Or in other words, will he survive the back stabbing and intrigues at KL since he can’t actually play the game?.

Westeros won’t transition from the medieval system into an “democracy” or whatever they’re going for without a revolution and the Lords won’t stop fighting for power because the last Targaryen has gone to the Wall and will “never” have children. E.g. the Iron born will not submit easily to a centralised power. Specially if such power is actually a crippled boy and a Lannister imp. Tyrion is a father slayer btw, kind of like Jon is an aunt slayer. And they both murdered women that were their lovers.

In conclusion.

I love Bran but left face it, Westerosis like Dothraki don’t follow the weak.

2. Jon.

Even after becoming Queenslayer he’s still a contender for the main seat with the support of the North and potentially Riverlands, Vale and Stormlands, a military commander with plenty of experience and a war hero after the War with the dead.

All of this WITHOUT even considering he has the “right” blood. The Targs were deposed what? For twenty years?. Not even?. There are Targ loyalists still alive out there and ruling dinasties don’t just banish into thin air. I mean how long was the War of the Roses? Weren’t all Lancaster heirs persecuted for the hint of royal blood they had?. Weren’t the Warwicks still regarded as “rightful heirs” even during Henry VIII reign (and he was far more popular and successful than King Robert Baratheon for instance)?.

Even when the NW existed he was pestered by Stannis and others to claim his birthright to Winterfell (which he has through Lianna btw, although obvs Sansa, Arya and Bran and in the books Rickon are above him) and you expect me to believe Westerosi Lords will let him live quietly over there? Than no one will be offering their daughters in the hope of a Targ heir that they could use for power?.

But is Jon the best candidate?

Let’s look at the pros:

  1. He is a capable leader (brooding does not disqualify him).
  2. Tried his hand in administrative matters at the Wall.
  3. In spite of having drank Dorito’s kool aid (according to a scene that was completely occ), he still has a moral compass. A strong one like his mother and his foster dad.
  4. His coin landed on the right side and he has no nukes.
  5. He’s forgiving, not blood thirsty and has a talent for making allies of former enemies.
  6. He naturally attracts people and they love him. Yes, charismatic leaders are not necessarily the best but it certainly helps.This is show canon episode 4.
  7. He fights for his family and the North but he also actively tried to stop the bloodbath in KL, as much as one could stop a dragon firing naplam from the sky. That means he cares for southerners as well.
  8. After all is said and done now we all “know what happens when people find out the truth” about him. People will be willing to lose their heads to put him in power and the scheming won’t stop simply because the Wall is far.

Let’s look at the cons:

  1. Queenslayer? That’ll make him King actually by right of conquest. Case in point Henry Tudor literally grabbing Richard’s crown from his dead body.
  2. He doesn’t want it. No matter what he wants. Now we all “know what happens when people hear the truth about you”. Show canon.

Side note: when at Craster’s he tells Commander Mormont he does have ambition for ruling. Show canon. Season 3? I’m not sure.

In conclusion.

He may be enjoying his pleasure trip up North for the moment but I don’t think he’ll have to wait ten years or even one before the political situation deteriorates, someone tries to kill him or kidnap him to force others to act. Or to Bran or Sansa.

To paraphrase Jon’s second greatest supporter:

Nothing lasts. Not even eternal exile.

summary: old Nan: anyway among the walkers was Night King. He was so scary, alive nighma- little Bran: wow! Cool! Can someone be friends...
body:
old Nan: anyway among the walkers was Night King. He was so scary, alive nighma-
little Bran: wow! Cool! Can someone be friends with him?
old Nan:
old Nan: well, probably, if you are a king too, yes.
little Bran: got it.

summary: Kelsey L. Hayes's answer to Loads of people have complained that Bran should have warged into Drogon to save King's Landing but...
body:
Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to Loads of people have complained that Bran should have warged into Drogon to save King’s Landing but isn’t it pos

I feel like certain s tans are really desperate to absolve Dany of all responsibility or to try make it seem it’s not in character for Dany to do what she did. This time it seems Bran “should” have tried to control Drogon so if something goes wrong, Bran can take the fall. Ack!

———-

I seem to recall someone asking GRRM about dragons being, uh, warg-able, and he declined to say yes or no (which is GRRM-speak for, “It’s possible”).


I also think the Valyrians avoided Westeros before Aegon I because they feared what wargs could do with their dragons, and that the ancient Hardhome disaster could have been a bungled Valyrian expedition gone wrong.


See:


Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to A Song of Ice and Fire (book series): Why didn’t the Valyrian Freehold invade Westeros?


Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to What do you think about the Valyrian Invasion of Hardhome Theory?


Having said that, I 100% loathe the “Bran should have warged Drogon to save King’s Landing!” argument, because that places responsibility for what happened on Bran instead of on the person who actually did it, Dany. Bran could have warged Drogon at any time and that still wouldn’t make Dany any less responsible for what she did

Bran could have warged Drogon at any time and that still wouldn’t make Dany any less responsible for what she did

Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to A Song of Ice and Fire (book series): Why didn’t the Valyrian Freehold invade Westeros?


Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to What do you think about the Valyrian Invasion of Hardhome Theory?


Having said that, I 100% loathe the “Bran should have warged Drogon to save King’s Landing!” argument, because that places responsibility for what happened on Bran instead of on the person who actually did it, Dany. Bran could have warged Drogon at any time and that still wouldn’t make Dany any less responsible for what she did
trail.content:
Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to Loads of people have complained that Bran should have warged into Drogon to save King’s Landing but isn’t it pos

I feel like certain s tans are really desperate to absolve Dany of all responsibility or to try make it seem it’s not in character for Dany to do what she did. This time it seems Bran “should” have tried to control Drogon so if something goes wrong, Bran can take the fall. Ack!

———-

I seem to recall someone asking GRRM about dragons being, uh, warg-able, and he declined to say yes or no (which is GRRM-speak for, “It’s possible”).


I also think the Valyrians avoided Westeros before Aegon I because they feared what wargs could do with their dragons, and that the ancient Hardhome disaster could have been a bungled Valyrian expedition gone wrong.


See:


Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to A Song of Ice and Fire (book series): Why didn’t the Valyrian Freehold invade Westeros?


Kelsey L. Hayes’s answer to What do you think about the Valyrian Invasion of Hardhome Theory?


Having said that, I 100% loathe the “Bran should have warged Drogon to save King’s Landing!” argument, because that places responsibility for what happened on Bran instead of on the person who actually did it, Dany. Bran could have warged Drogon at any time and that still wouldn’t make Dany any less responsible for what she did

blog.name: twhiddlegirl
blog.title: - I'm freaky -
blog.description:
“You,” Ned said, kissing her lightly on the brow, “will marry a king and rule his castle, and your sons will be knights and princes and lords and, yes, perhaps even a High Septon.”
"Corn,” the bird said, and, “King," and, “Snow, Jon Snow, Jon Snow.” That was queer. The bird had never said his full name before, as best Jon could recall.
Bring her home, Mance... You owe me this one little girl.
She found herself wishing that Jon was here with her now.
What do you know of my heart, priestess? What do you know of my sister?
Needle was Jon Snow's smile.﻿

summary: Am I the only one who sees this?
title: Am I the only one who sees this?
body:
So, Game of Thrones is over, and Bran is king. Whether that’s good news or not depends on how one views Bran as a character.

What I do notice, however, is that whether people approve or disapprove of Bran as king, their reasons for or against focus entirely on Bran as a person and not on the circumstances surrounding his ascent to the throne. From this individualistic perspective, King Bran may seem to come out of nowhere. But taking a bird’s eye view (pun intended) and looking at the situation as it stands for most people, King Bran makes a lot of sense.

Look at what we’re dealing with: The populace of Westeros has been ravaged by a series of bloody, devastating wars. Entire great houses have been eradicated, and others are hanging on by a thread. We’re not even talking civilian casualties, casualties that disrupt trade, commerce, agriculture and infrastructure.

Then there’s the psychological toll. People are fucking exhausted. People have been killing and dying for the Iron Throne virtually non-stop since the death of Robert Baratheon. But they can’t rebuild the kingdom with this gaping power vacuum staring them in the face. Someone has to be in charge, but who?

Whoever the people can live with. In other words, the person least likely to drag the people into another war over who gets to sit in an ugly chair. The person who most fits that bill is Bran. Due to his disability and his detachment from the usual things that motivate people, he’s the least offensive choice. He is (or seems) harmless.

After weeks in a prison cell with nothing to do but think, Tyrion knows this. He also knows that compared to the inspiring, passionate, beautiful Dany and strong, honorable, handsome Jon, a quiet, reserved boy in a wheelchair would not be eagerly embraced as king material.

And this is where Tyrion’s stroke of genius comes in. Stories do unite people. But Bran having the best story? With Sansa and Arya right there, Jon in a prison cell and Dany barely cold in the grave? With his own colorful life? Please. That’s pure bullshit. It’s spin. It’s the PR campaign to sell the nobility on the idea of Bran being king.

It’s quite brilliant, really.

(This is a huge moment of character development for Tyrion, where he grows beyond clever and becomes wise.)

summary: Shout out to my girl Meera who deserves all the happiness she can get! Bran now that you're king you're going to properly...
body: Shout out to my girl Meera who deserves all the happiness she can get! Bran now that you’re king you’re going to properly apologize to a girl who dragged your ass to safety and loves you and you’re going to marry her. I still support Breera ship even after everything that’s happened. Meera you can slap Bran to get him out of his emo mode.

Jaime pushed Bran out of the “Broken Tower” in episode one.

summary: What if the writers of the show meant for Bran to, not just be the 3ER, but to actually be Brynden Rivers? What if they left it...
question: What if the writers of the show meant for Bran to, not just be the 3ER, but to actually be Brynden Rivers? What if they left it open so that book readers can draw different conclusions? That scene with Tyrion in 8.04 Bran said about the wheelchair "It's the same as the one Daeron Targaryen built for his crippled nephew 120 years ago." And who Brynden fought for in the rebellion? For King Daeron Targaryen! My mind is reeling now, I mean that line coudn't have been thrown randomly, right?! ...
answer:
I’m ngl anon, much as I love this train of thought, I don’t actually think D&D particularly meant anything deep by that writing. I suspect they just threw that line in there as a reference to previous Westerosi lore, that’s it. Nothing about any of the writing this season makes me think anything was written beyond surface level (at least, not in 803-806, 801-802 I do think it was because it wasn’t D&D and they were written by competent writers who care massively about the characters).

However, the good thing about their writing being so shambolic is it leaves us able to draw a lot of our own conclusions which admittedly is actually a bad thing the audience shouldn’t be the ones doing the work here so if you want to believe Bran is also Brynden Rivers by being the 3ER then go for it! The evidence is there if you want to believe it, and I love that theory - I just don’t think it was deliberately done. I do think it was thrown in randomly, unfortunately.
